#include "client.hpp"

client::client(const std::string& host, short port)
    : socket_(io_context_) 
{
    boost::asio::ip::tcp::resolver resolver(io_context_);
    boost::asio::connect(socket_, resolver.resolve(host, std::to_string(port)));
}

void client::send_move_command(const std::string& direction, int distance) {
    std::string message = direction + " " + std::to_string(distance) + "\n";
    boost::asio::write(socket_, boost::asio::buffer(message));
    std::cout << "Sent: " << message << std::endl;
}

void client::run() {
    while (true) {
        std::string direction;
        int distance;

        std::cout << "Enter movement direction (up, down, left, right): ";
        std::cin >> direction;

        std::cout << "Enter distance to move: ";
        std::cin >> distance;

        if (direction == "quit") {
            std::cout << "Exiting..." << std::endl;
            break;
        }

        send_move_command(direction, distance);
    }
}

#include "vector2d.hpp"

Vector2D::Vector2D(int x, int y) : x(x), y(y) {}

void Vector2D::move(const std::string& direction) {
    std::string dir_upper = direction;
    std::transform(dir_upper.begin(), dir_upper.end(), dir_upper.begin(), ::toupper); // Convertit en majuscules

    if (dir_upper == "UP")       y -= 1;
    else if (dir_upper == "DOWN") y += 1;
    else if (dir_upper == "LEFT") x -= 1;
    else if (dir_upper == "RIGHT") x += 1;
}
std::string Vector2D::to_string() const {
    return "(" + std::to_string(x) + ", " + std::to_string(y) + ")";
}

#include "server.hpp"
#include "session.hpp"
#include <boost/asio.hpp>
#include <iostream>

// Constructor
server::server(boost::asio::io_context& io_context, short port)
    : io_context_(io_context),
      acceptor_(io_context, tcp::endpoint(tcp::v4(), port)) {
    start_accept();
}

// Start accepting new connections
void server::start_accept() {
    acceptor_.async_accept(
        [this](boost::system::error_code ec, tcp::socket socket) {
            if (!ec) {
                std::cout << "New client connected: "
                          << socket.remote_endpoint().address().to_string() << std::endl;
                std::make_shared<session>(std::move(socket))->run();
            } else {
                std::cerr << "Error on accept: " << ec.message() << std::endl;
            }
            start_accept();
        });
}

docs.title: session.cpp
docs.text:
#include "session.hpp"
#include <boost/asio.hpp>
#include <iostream>
#include <string>

// Constructor
session::session(tcp::socket socket)
    : m_socket(std::move(socket)), position(0, 0) {
    directions_ = {
        {"up", {0, 1}},
        {"down", {0, -1}},
        {"left", {-1, 0}},
        {"right", {1, 0}}
    };
}

// Run the session and wait for commands
void session::run() {
    wait_for_command();
}

// Wait for a command from the client
void session::wait_for_command() {
    auto self(shared_from_this());
    boost::asio::async_read_until(m_socket, m_buffer, '\n',
        [this, self](boost::system::error_code ec, std::size_t length) {
            if (!ec) {
                std::istream is(&m_buffer);
                std::string message;
                std::getline(is, message);

                size_t space_pos = message.find(' ');
                if (space_pos != std::string::npos) {
                    std::string direction = message.substr(0, space_pos);
                    int distance = std::stoi(message.substr(space_pos + 1));

                    handle_move(direction, distance);  // Met à jour la position
                } else {
                    std::cerr << "Invalid command format: " << message << std::endl;
                }

                send_position();  // Retourne la position mise à jour
                wait_for_command();
            } else {
                std::cerr << "Error reading message: " << ec.message() << std::endl;
            }
        });
}

// Send the updated position to the client
void session::send_position() {
    auto self(shared_from_this());
    std::string message = "Position: " + position.to_string() + "\n";
    boost::asio::async_write(m_socket, boost::asio::buffer(message),
        [this, self](boost::system::error_code ec, std::size_t) {
            if (ec) {
                std::cerr << "Error sending position: " << ec.message() << std::endl;
            }
        });
}

// Handle movement based on direction and distance
void session::handle_move(const std::string& direction, int distance) {
    if (directions_.find(direction) != directions_.end()) {
        auto movement = directions_[direction];
        position.move(movement.first * distance, movement.second * distance);

        std::cout << "Moved " << direction << " by " << distance << " units. "
                  << "New position: " << position.to_string() << std::endl;
    } else {
        std::cerr << "Invalid direction: " << direction << std::endl;
    }
}

#include "vector2d.hpp"
#include <array>
#include <iostream>

// Constructor
Vector2D::Vector2D(int x, int y) {
    coordinates[0] = x;  // Initialiser la coordonnée X
    coordinates[1] = y;  // Initialiser la coordonnée Y
}

// Move by delta values
void Vector2D::move(int dx, int dy) {
    coordinates[0] += dx;  // Déplacer la coordonnée X
    coordinates[1] += dy;  // Déplacer la coordonnée Y
}

// Move based on direction
void Vector2D::move(const std::string& direction) {
    if (direction == "UP") {
        coordinates[1] -= 1;  // Déplacer vers le haut
    }
    else if (direction == "DOWN") {
        coordinates[1] += 1;  // Déplacer vers le bas
    }
    else if (direction == "LEFT") {
        coordinates[0] -= 1;  // Déplacer vers la gauche
    }
    else if (direction == "RIGHT") {
        coordinates[0] += 1;  // Déplacer vers la droite
    }
}

// Convert position to string
std::string Vector2D::to_string() const {
    return "(" + std::to_string(coordinates[0]) + ", " + std::to_string(coordinates[1]) + ")";
}

// Getter for x-coordinate
int Vector2D::get_x() const {
    return coordinates[0];
}

// Getter for y-coordinate
int Vector2D::get_y() const {
    return coordinates[1];
}

// Setter for x-coordinate
void Vector2D::set_x(int value) {
    coordinates[0] = value;
}

// Setter for y-coordinate
void Vector2D::set_y(int value) {
    coordinates[1] = value;
}

#include "ConfigParser.hpp"
#include <fstream>
#include <stdexcept>
#include <sstream>

std::map<std::string, std::map<std::string, std::string>> ConfigParser::parse(const std::string& filePath) {
    std::ifstream file(filePath);
    if (!file.is_open()) {
        throw std::runtime_error("Impossible d'ouvrir le fichier : " + filePath);
    }

    std::map<std::string, std::map<std::string, std::string>> iniData;
    std::string currentSection;

    std::string line;
    while (std::getline(file, line)) {
        // Ignore les lignes vides ou les commentaires
        if (line.empty() || line[0] == ';') continue;

        // Section
        if (line[0] == '[' && line.back() == ']') {
            currentSection = line.substr(1, line.size() - 2);
            iniData[currentSection] = {};
        } else {
            // Clé = Valeur
            size_t delimiterPos = line.find('=');
            if (delimiterPos != std::string::npos) {
                std::string key = line.substr(0, delimiterPos);
                std::string value = line.substr(delimiterPos + 1);
                iniData[currentSection][key] = value;
            }
        }
    }

    if (iniData.empty()) {
        throw std::runtime_error("Le fichier INI est vide ou mal formaté.");
    }

    return iniData;
}

#include "Room.hpp"
#include "ConfigParser.hpp" // Inclure le parser
#include <iostream>
#include <stdexcept>

Room::Room(int number, const std::string& type, int capacity)
    : roomNumber(number), roomType(type) {
    setRoomCapacity(capacity);
}

Room::~Room() {}

// Getters
int Room::getRoomNumber() const { return roomNumber; }

std::string Room::getRoomType() const { return roomType; }

int Room::getRoomCapacity() const { return roomCapacity; }

// Setters
void Room::setRoomNumber(int number) { roomNumber = number; }

void Room::setRoomType(const std::string& type) { roomType = type; }

void Room::setRoomCapacity(int capacity) {
    if (roomType == "solo" && capacity != 1) {
        throw std::invalid_argument("La capacité d'une salle Solo doit être 1");
    } else if ((roomType == "multi" || roomType == "infini") && capacity > 4) {
        throw std::invalid_argument("La capacité d'une salle Multi ou Infini doit être au maximum 4");
    }
    roomCapacity = capacity;
}

// Afficher les informations de la salle
void Room::displayRoomInfo() const {
    std::cout << "Room Number: " << roomNumber << std::endl;
    std::cout << "Room Type: " << roomType << std::endl;
    std::cout << "Room Capacity: " << roomCapacity << std::endl;
}

// Charger les salles depuis le fichier INI
std::vector<Room> Room::loadRoomsFromConfig(const std::string& filePath) {
    auto config = ConfigParser::parse(filePath); // Appel du parser
    std::vector<Room> rooms;
    int roomNumber = 1;

    for (const auto& [section, properties] : config) {
        if (properties.find("maxcapacity") == properties.end() || properties.find("roomtype") == properties.end()) {
            throw std::invalid_argument("Clé manquante dans la section : " + section);
        }

        std::string type = properties.at("roomtype");
        int capacity;

        try {
            capacity = std::stoi(properties.at("maxcapacity"));
        } catch (const std::invalid_argument& e) {
            throw std::invalid_argument("Capacité invalide pour la salle dans la section : " + section);
        } catch (const std::out_of_range& e) {
            throw std::out_of_range("Capacité trop grande pour la salle dans la section : " + section);
        }

        rooms.emplace_back(roomNumber++, type, capacity);
    }

    return rooms;
}

@brief implements the Grisu2 algorithm for binary to decimal floating-point conversion.

This implementation is a slightly modified version of the reference implementation which may be obtained from http://florian.loitsch.com/publications (bench.tar.gz).

The code is distributed under the MIT license, Copyright (c) 2009 Florian Loitsch.

For a detailed description of the algorithm see:

[1] Loitsch, "Printing Floating-Point Numbers Quickly and Accurately with Integers", Proceedings of the ACM SIGPLAN 2010 Conference on Programming Language Design and Implementation, PLDI 2010 [2] Burger, Dybvig, "Printing Floating-Point Numbers Quickly and Accurately", Proceedings of the ACM SIGPLAN 1996 Conference on Programming Language Design and Implementation, PLDI 1996

docs.text: Name Description Colors This class defined a good set of ANSI colors. CxxABI Wrapper around usefull C++/C low level functions Got demangle, backtrace... !!! tip This class is only made of static functions. It does not contain constructor, nor destructor This means that you don't need to instanciate it, and only use it as if it was a namespace. Exception Wrapper arround default std::exception Store the the exception description as std::string, and store some usefull localisation informations: Filename, Line, and Function Name. This is automated using the throw_exception preprocessor directive. !!! tip Take a look at the NotImplementedError to see how easy it is to implmeent your own Flint::Exception. Inspection Base class to implement simplet self-reflexion in C++ T : Child class itself !!! tip When creating a child class, define as follow : cpp class ChildClass: public Inspection<ChildClass> This will extand the ChildClass with the self-reflexion class Inspection !!! warning If the class you want to extand as a reflected class will be a parent class (I.E. You will create childs of this "target" class), you might want to mark inheritence as virtual. This is needed if your child class also need to be reflected. This way, there is no confilict between the parent reflexion, and the child reflexion. NotImplementedError Sample Flint::Exceptions::Exception to register NotImplemented features !!! tip You should use that Exception as a C++ Implementation of the Rust todo!() macro. !!! example cpp throw_exception(Flint::Exceptions::NotImplementedError, "This function haven't been implemented as of today !");

docs.title: Exception
docs.text:
class Exception: public std::exception

Wrapper arround default std::exception

Store the the exception description as std::string, and store some usefull localisation informations: Filename, Line, and Function Name. This is automated using the throw_exception preprocessor directive.

Tip

Take a look at the NotImplementedError to see how easy it is to implmeent your own Flint::Exception.

docs.title: Exception
docs.text:
Exception(const std::string& what = "An exception occured !", std::pair<std::pair<std::string, std::size_t>, std::string> infos = {{"", 0}, ""})

Exception constructor. This need to be called, even on child classes.

what Define the exception's description infos Might contain positional infos

Warning

You should NOT use any excpetion constructor manually. While they might work, the prefered way is to use the throw_exception preprocessor directive. Using it will only require you to register what type of excpetion you want to throw, and what message you want to add, and will take care of putting file name, line, and function name

docs.title: getClassNameFromStackTrace
docs.text:
std::string getClassNameFromStackTrace(const std::vector<std::pair<std::string, std::size_t>>& stackTrace) const

Try to retreive the Exception class name from the StackTrace.

stackTrace A stack trace, formated like CxxABI::getBacktrace()

Warning

This function DOES NOT WORK 100% OF THE TIME. It is really dependant on the environement, and can return undefined without aparent reason. It should NOT be used for anything else than debug or display.

Return The actual class name or "[Class name undefined]"

docs.title: show
docs.text:
std::string show(std::pair<std::pair<std::string, std::size_t>, std::string> infos) const

Display the error, given specific positional infos (like the constructor).

infos Positional informations, like the constructor, used to display the infos.

Note

This function, while being usable without, should be used through the catch_exception preprocessor directive. This preprocessor directive let you display Python like excpetion trace.

Return The formated exception, ready to be displayed.

docs.title: what
docs.text:
const char* what() const noexcept override

Required override, deprecated by show and catch_exception.

Info

This is the required std::exception override. It'll return the _what as a const char*. While this will work, prefer using the show function or the catch_excpetion preprocessor directive :

Example

try {
    throw_exception(Flint::Exceptions::Exception, "Sample testing exception");
} catch (const Flint::Exceptions::Exception& e) {
    std::cerr << catch_exception(e) << std::endl;
}
Return The _what as a C string

docs.title: Inspection
docs.text:
template <typename T> class Inspection

Base class to implement simplet self-reflexion in C++

T Child class itself

Tip

When creating a child class, define as follow : 

class ChildClass: public Inspection<ChildClass>
This will extand the ChildClass with the self-reflexion class Inspection

Warning

If the class you want to extand as a reflected class will be a parent class (I.E. You will create childs of this "target" class), you might want to mark inheritence as virtual. This is needed if your child class also need to be reflected. This way, there is no confilict between the parent reflexion, and the child reflexion.

docs.title: Operators
docs.text: Name Description operator<< Overload the operator << to use the str method of the object T : Reflected class os : Reference of ostream (I.E. std::cout, std::cerr...) obj : Object reference to be displayed Return : Param os

docs.title: Functions
docs.text: Name Description getClassName Return the name of the reflected class Return : The demangled name of the class, or just the name, if demangleing failed str Return a string representation of the class !!! tip This function is not intended to be used. This is because this functions display the reflection. You might prefer to override this function in yout child class to display informations that are more relevant to your specific class. !!! example You have a Macro available to make the str function really easilly : cpp display_attr(attribute) Which will automaticly translate to cpp Flint::Colors::F_BLUE << "attribute" << Flint::Colors::RESET << "=" << Flint::Colors::RED << this->attribute << Flint::Colors::RESET There is also a make_str macro, which you can use as follow : cpp return make_str("a=12" << ", " << "b=5"); that becomes cpp return ({std::stringstream ss; ss << "<" << this->getClassName() << " at " << std::hex << this << ": " << "a=12" << ", " << "b=5" << ">"; ss.str()}) It means you can define the str function of your class as like that : cpp // Provided you have 3 attributes called a, b and c return make_str(display_attr(a) << ", " << display_attr(b) << ", " << display_attr(c)); Return : The string representation of the class

docs.title: str
docs.text:
virtual std::string str() const

Return a string representation of the class

Tip

This function is not intended to be used. This is because this functions display the reflection. You might prefer to override this function in yout child class to display informations that are more relevant to your specific class.

Example

You have a Macro available to make the str function really easilly : 

display_attr(attribute)
Which will automaticly translate to 
Flint::Colors::F_BLUE << "attribute" << Flint::Colors::RESET << "=" << Flint::Colors::RED << this->attribute << Flint::Colors::RESET
There is also a make_str macro, which you can use as follow : 
return make_str("a=12" << ", " << "b=5");
that becomes 
return ({std::stringstream ss; ss << "<" << this->getClassName() << " at " << std::hex << this << ": " << "a=12" << ", " << "b=5" << ">"; ss.str()})
It means you can define the str function of your class as like that : 
// Provided you have 3 attributes called a, b and c
return make_str(display_attr(a) << ", " << display_attr(b) << ", " << display_attr(c));

Return The string representation of the class

docs.title: NotImplementedError
docs.text:
class NotImplementedError: public Flint::Exceptions::Exception

Sample Flint::Exceptions::Exception to register NotImplemented features

Tip

You should use that Exception as a C++ Implementation of the Rust todo!() macro.

Example

throw_exception(Flint::Exceptions::NotImplementedError, "This function haven't been implemented as of today !");

docs.title: iterator_category
docs.text:
using iterator_category = std::bidirectional_iterator_tag

    The std::iterator class template (used as a base class to provide typedefs) is deprecated in C++17.
    The C++ Standard has never required user-defined iterators to derive from std::iterator.
    A user-defined iterator should provide publicly accessible typedefs named
    iterator_category, value_type, difference_type, pointer, and reference.
    Note that value_type is required to be non-const, even for constant iterators.

docs.title: token_type
docs.text:
enum class token_type

token types for the parser

uninitialized indicating the scanner is uninitialized literal_true the true literal literal_false the false literal literal_null the null literal value_string a string -- use get_string() for actual value value_unsigned an unsigned integer -- use get_number_unsigned() for actual value value_integer a signed integer -- use get_number_integer() for actual value value_float an floating point number -- use get_number_float() for actual value begin_array the character for array begin [ begin_object the character for object begin { end_array the character for array end ] end_object the character for object end } name_separator the name separator : value_separator the value separator , parse_error indicating a parse error end_of_input indicating the end of the input buffer literal_or_value a literal or the begin of a value (only for diagnostics)

docs.title: Network
docs.text: Custom classes handeling all the networking. This allows you to create your own network wrapper (Hell, you could play through HTTP WebSockets if you want ! (Don't do that please)).

docs.title: Server
docs.text: As important as all of the other parts (if not more), the server is the masterchief of the orchestra. It connect all players, and handle all the game logic.
